STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 14, 2024
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St,
Ypsilanti, MI, 48198-5707
RE: License#: CP810201490
Dear Ms. Adorjan:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9//27/2024. An Exit confernce was held with the agency on 10/3/2024. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
Enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Renee Adorjan
Name of Agency: WASHTENAW COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 22 CENTER ST
YPSILANTI, MI 48198-5707
Agency Telephone #: 7344818364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 9/24/24, 9/25/24, 9/26/24, 9/27/24
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 17 4
Homes pending licensure 9 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 6 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 12 4
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 46 6
Children discharged from care during this period 58 6
Youth in independent living placement 3 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 0 0
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection N/A N/A
Open child adoption cases
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 13 5
Less than a year 3 3
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 1
Adoption Staff 0
Supervisory Staff 1
Administrative Staff 2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 12 3
Unlicensed relative homes 18 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 4
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Two of eight personnel records reviewed did the show compliance:
• One record showed the employee's probationary evaluation was due by
2/10/2024 and completed late on 3/18/2024.
• A second record showed the employee's six months evaluation after
promotion to a new position was due by 6/13/2024 and was completed late
on 7/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request.
(3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application
for renewal of the license and document the action not
less than 60 calendar days before the expiration date
of the license. A renewal application must be provided
to a licensee, regardless of any pending
recommendation for disciplinary action of the license.

Two of four open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation that
an application was provided to the foster parents at least 60 days prior to the
respective foster home's 1/29/2024 and 4/17/2024 license expiration date.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a
determination and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with,
each member of the household and each social service
worker who has had children placed in the home during
the last licensing period.
Three of four open foster home records reviewed did not show compliance:
• Two records did not show documentation of both strengths and
weaknesses of the foster parents as assessed by the worker or as
reported by the foster parents, as required for the re-evaluation.
• A third record did not show documentation that a worker who had a child
placed in the foster home was interviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
One of four open foster home records reviewed showed the licensing
recommendation was not submitted at least 15 days prior to the foster home's
4/17/2024 expiration date.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
Six of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023

Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Six of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (b)
as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023
Renewal Inspection 2022 , CAP approved 10/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed the record showed the child's
initial dental exam was due by 12/24/2023, and completed late on 4/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical
authority, which indicates that immunizations are
current or contraindicated, is sufficient documentation
of immunizations.

In one of six open foster child records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation of the child's updated DTP/DTaP/DT/DP/Tdap immunization which
expired 9/13/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (c), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (d), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (e), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.

Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (f), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (g), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home as provided in federal law.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
the caregiver was provided with the information identified in (h), as specified by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
Two of six open foster child records reviewed( where an intial service plan was
due on four of the cases) did not show documentation of (c) as required by the
rule.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.

Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
In three of six open foster child records reviewed (where an initial service plan
was due on four of the cases), the initial service plan did not show documentation
of a specific behavior support plan for the child.
Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.
In three of six open foster child records reviewed, the updated service plan did
not show documentation of a specific behavior support plan for the child.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed where siblings were split, the
record did not show documentation of an April, May or June 2024 sibling visit.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.

(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
In one of three independent living youth records reviewed, the record did not
show documentation of the youth's updated dental and medical examination due
by 2/12/2024 and 5/21/2024 respectively, nor a refusal of medical form signed by
the youth.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed, and one of three independent
living youth records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for a
reported 8/13/2024 FTM.
• A second child's record did not show documentation of a FTM for the
child's 12/19/2023-1/16/2024 ISP.
• A third child's record did not show documentation of a FTM for the child's
10/5/2023-1/2/2024 USP.
• The independent living youth records did not show documentation of an
FTM for the youths 11/9/2023-12/8/2023 ISP; nor the youths 12/9/23-
3/7/2024 or 6/6/2024-9/3/2024 USP. Additionally, the record did not show
documentation of a DHS-1105 for a reported FTM on 1/30/2024 and
5/9/2024.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.

FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Caseworker.
Supervisor.
Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages.
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Five of six open foster child records reviewed, and one of three independent living
youth records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's record did not show documentation of the child's 5/24/2024-
8/21/2024 treatment plan signed by the worker, supervisor, or birth mother
and caregiver.
• A second child's record did not show documentation of the child's
1/17/2024-4/3/2024 treatment plan signed by the worker, supervisor, or
birth mother and caregiver.
• A third child's record showed the child's 1/23/2024-4/21/2024 treatment
plan was not signed by the caregiver until 6/20/2024.
• A fourth child's record did not show documentation of the child's 5/3/2024-
7/31/2024 treatment plan signed by the caregiver.
• A fifth child's record did not show documentation of the child's 7/10/2024-
8/5/2024 treatment plan signed by the worker, supervisor, or birth parent
and caregiver.
• The independent living youth record did not show documentation of the
child's 11/9/2023-12/8/2023, 12/9/2023-3/7/2023 or 3/8/2024-6/5/2024
treatment plan signed by the worker, supervisor and youth.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
FOM 801-3 Medical Passport.

Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Note: Medical information is to be entered within five-
business days of receipt of the health information.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of an
updated July medical passport.
Interim Inspection 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023
Renewal Inspection 2022, CAP approved 10/31/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this Inspection
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. This CAP related to the agency’s 2023 Interim inspection
completed on 10/6/2024 where the CAP was approved on 12/11/2023. The
agency received 16 violations in that 2023 inspection 8 of which are repeat
violations this year. The agency’s compliance around these 6 rule violations is as
follows: 5 of them saw an increased related to the number of individual cases
cited: R400.12405(5) (a)&(b) increased from 1 of 5 to 6 of 6, R400.12419(1)(c)
increased from 1 of 5 to 2 of 4, R400.12420(g) increased from 1 of 6 to 3 of 6,
FOM 722-6B increased from 2 of 6 to 3 of 6, and FOM 722-8D increased from 3
of 6 to 5 of 6. As it relates to the other 2 repeat violations: R400.12421(4) stayed
the same at 1 of 6, while FOM 801-3 decreased from 3 of 6 to 1 of 6 for the
number of individual cases cited.
As it relates to the agency’s efforts to achieve the CAP, the agency provided
documentation showing:

• Its on line spreadsheet created to track CPR and first aid certification for
foster home. The agency did not receive any noncompliance in this area.
• Samples of foster care staff meeting agendas and supervisor meeting
agendas showing the discussions of CAP action items.
• Sample of emails showing reminders to staff related to report due dates
and time frames, as well as medical and dentals due dates and time frames
• The use of checklists was seen during licensing and foster care file reviews,
as were CPS transfer documents for five-day packages, and social work
contacts by the HLO (Health Liaison Officer) to family about initial
medicals/dentals.
The agency’s efforts to complete this CAP resulted in slight progress in various
areas. The agency was not totally successful with all, especially as it relates to
completion of DHS-69s, which when completed can show verification of
information required for R400.12405 -Change of placement. The agency reported
its staff’s lack of consistent document uploads contributes/impacts its
demonstrated compliance in some licensing areas. Notwithstanding, the agency
reports it will continue its efforts to improve, achieve and illustrate compliance in all
areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a chief administrator's report dated 6/30/2024. The
administrator reported the main barrier impacting compliance over the last year
related to areas cited in the last inspection was staffing changes. Additionally, that
the reason for repeat noncompliance, having an impact on the achievement of the
corrective action plan was all staff not fully understanding the audit’s findings,
despite multiple explanations, and supervisors not consistently using the tools
identified in the corrective action plan, as well as supervisors not ensuring FTMs
are held per policy, and that all documents are uploaded, as required.
The administrator also reported concern with the court ordering youths into/out of
placements without/against the agency's recommendation, which has resulted in
unplanned replacements for youths.
On an encouraging note, the administrator reported the agency has created a
spreadsheet to track CPR and first aid certifications for foster homes and it offers
in-person certification training twice a year for foster parents. Additionally, that
that the agency had regular CAP review meetings scheduled for the entire year,
and this information is shared at monthly foster care unit meetings, and in
individual case conferences. The administrator also reported the agency has
secured a supervisor loan from another county and it continues to try to secure
additional staff as able.
Financial Overview
Not applicable, this is a state agency.
Staff and Youth Interviews

In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, section manager, and one
supervisor during the entrance conference, I interviewed three foster care workers,
and a licensing worker. Staff reported team camaraderie, managerial support, the
agency’s great efforts to meet timeframes and deadline, and co-workers kindness
and willingness to help with client referrals/resources. Areas of limitations
reported included, inconsistency in the timeliness of communication, the need for
more staff, more consistent demonstrated staff support, and having a mentor
assigned to new staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the site area was conducted and did not reveal any safety
concerns. Case files were properly stored and secured.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
October 10, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 14, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Area Manager
